{{Infobox person | name = Erwan Le Corre | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name --> | birth_date ={{Birth date and age |1971|9|10|df=y}} | birth_place =France | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | | known for =Founder of MovNat | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Erwan Le Corre''', a French American born on September 10, 1971,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.movnat.com/erwan-le-corre/ |title=Erwan Le Corre |publisher=MovNat website, About Us, Erwan Le Corre |access-date= 3 May 2015}}</ref> is the founder and innovator of a physical education system and lifestyle<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sensualanimist.com/2012/03/10/paleofitness-and-movnat/ |title=PaleoFitness and MovNat |publisher=Sensualanimist |access-date= 11 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/10/fashion/10caveman.html?_r=0 |title=The New Age Caveman and the City |publisher= The New York Times |access-date=14 June 2015}}</ref> known as MovNat, which derives from the French words "mouvement naturel" ("natural movement").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.menshealth.com/fitness/fitness-survive-wild |title=A Wild Workout for the Real World |publisher=Men's Health |access-date= 3 May 2015}}</ref>
== Early life and training ==
Erwan Le Corre grew up in the French village of [[Étréchy, Essonne|Étréchy]], and later at [[Épinay-sur-Orge]], both south of Paris. As a child he spent his free time outdoors exploring and playing in the fields and woods around his village. At age 18, Le Corre received a black belt in Karate. Starting at age 19 he did [[parkour]]-like training for 7 years with the Parisian stuntman Don Jean Habrey. During this period he also began barefoot running.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://conditioningresearch.blogspot.com/2009/01/erwan-le-corre.html |title=Interview with Erwan Le Corre |publisher=Conditioning Research |access-date= 11 May 2015}}</ref> At age 27, he began a period of training which included sailing, Olympic weightlifting, rock climbing, long distance triathlon, trail running and Brazilian jiu-jitsu.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.movnat.com/erwan-le-corre/ |title=Erwan Le Corre |publisher=MovNat website, About Us, Erwan Le Corre |access-date= 3 May 2015}}</ref>
== Development of a system of natural movement ==
In 2004 Erwan Le Corre started researching the physical training method of the French naval officer [[Georges Hébert]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.outsideonline.com/1896516/workout-time-forgot |title=The Workout Time Forgot |publisher=Outside Online |access-date=3 May 2015}}</ref> The training developed by Hébert is known as "la méthode naturelle" ("natural method").<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.menshealth.com/fitness/fitness-survive-wild |title= A Wild Workout for the Real World|publisher=Men's Health |access-date= 14 August 2015}}</ref> In 2008 Le Corre formally began his physical education system and lifestyle known as MovNat<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/wellness/movnat-learning-how-to-move-as-we-were-intended-to/2012/02/03/gIQABjNMRR_story.html |title=MovNat: Learning how to move as we were intended to|publisher=The Washington Post |access-date= 3 May 2015}}</ref> and began teaching it in weekend workshops and weeklong outdoor retreats.
In the 2010s Le Corre was based near [[Santa Fe, New Mexico|Santa Fe]], [[New Mexico]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nancercize.net/2012/08/31/interview-with-movnats-erwan-le-corre/ |title=Interview with MovNat's Erwan Le Corre |publisher=Nancercise: The Benchmark in Outdoor Fitness |access-date= 3 May 2015}}</ref>.
== MovNat ==
According to Le Corre, MovNat is "a school of physical competency entirely based on natural movement, which includes the locomotive skills of walking, running, balancing, crawling, jumping, climbing and swimming, the manipulative skills of lifting, carrying, throwing and catching, and the defensive skills of striking and grappling[,and that t]he most important principles of natural movement are practicality and adaptability."<ref>{{cite book |last=Bowman |first=Katy |authorlink=|date=2015 |title=Whole Body Barefoot: Transitioning to Minimal Footwear}}</ref>
Regarding the difference between Hébert's "méthode naturelle" and Le Corre's MovNat, Le Corre has said that "the main difference resides in the coaching system, which has been updated. It is more elaborate and efficient in MovNat.... MovNat's philosophy is formulated to better fit with today using modern forms of communication, for instance video and the Internet."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefitnessexplorer.com/home/2010/11/20/300-second-interview-erwan-le-corre-movnat.html |title=300 Second Interview: Erwan Le Corre (MovNat)|publisher=The Fitness Explorer |access-date= 3 May 2015}}</ref>
==Publications== Le Corre is releasing his first book entitled ''The Practice of Natural Movement: Reclaim Power, Health and Freedom.''<ref>{{Cite book |last=Le Corre |first=Erwan |isbn=978-1628602838 |title=The Practice of Natural Movement: Reclaim Power, Health, and Freedom|publisher=Amazon.com }}<!--|access-date=7 May 2015--></ref>
== See also ==
* [[Functional training]] * [[Barefoot running]] * [[Fitness trail]] * [[Green exercise]]
== References == {{wikiquote|Erwan Le Corre}}
{{Reflist}}
==Sources==
* Angel, Julie (2016). ''Breaking the Jump: The Secret Story of Parkour's High Flying Rebellion'', Arum Press. * Durant, John (2013). ''The Paleo Manifesto: Ancient Wisdom for Lifelong Health'', Harmony Books (Random House). *[[Christopher McDougall|McDougall, Christopher]] (2015). ''Natural Born Heroes: How A Daring Band of Misfits Mastered the Lost Secrets of Strength and Endurance'', Vintage.
==Further reading==
* Bowman, Katy (2014). ''Move Your DNA: Restore Your Health Through Natural Movement'', Propriometrics Press.

{{Infobox stadium | name = Parque Artigas | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | location = | coordinates = {{Coord|32.322694|S|58.072384|W|type:landmark|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1994 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Paysandú Department]] | operator = | surface = grass | scoreboard = | cost = | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 25,000 | suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Paysandú F.C.]]
[[Club Paysandú Bella Vista]] | embedded = }} '''Estadio Parque Artigas''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Paysandú]], [[Uruguay]]. It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches of [[Paysandú F.C.]] The stadium holds 25,000 and was built in 1994.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/south_america/countries/uruguay.shtml|title=Stadiums in Uruguay|work=Worldstadiums.com|accessdate=8 September 2011}} It hosted matches during the [[1995 Copa America]]. ==References== [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Uruguay|Parque Artigas]] [[Category:Football venues in Uruguay|Parque Artigas]] [[Category:Copa América stadiums]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1994]] [[Category:1994 establishments in Uruguay]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Paysandú Department]] {{Uruguay-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} {{Infobox sports club | name = Ethnikos G.S. Athens | logo = | caption = | full_name = Ethnikos Gymnastikos Syllogos | nicknames = | founded = 1893 | colours = {{color box|black}} {{color box|white}} [[Black]], [[White]] | president = | club_titles = | anthem = | website = [http://www.ethnikosgs.gr ethnikosgs.gr] }} '''Ethnikos Gymnastikos Syllogos''' or '''Ethnikos Athens''' is one of the oldest multi-sports clubs in [[Greece]]. It was founded in 1893.
==History==
===1896 Olympics=== [[File:Ioannis Mitropoulos.JPG|thumb|140px|[[Ioannis Mitropoulos]]]] [[File:Panagiotis Paraskevopoulos.JPG|thumb|140px|[[Panagiotis Paraskevopoulos]]]]
It had a team of [[gymnastics|gymnasts]] competing at the [[1896 Summer Olympics]] in [[Athens]].
The team's leader was [[Ioannis Chrysafis]]. Members included [[Ioannis Mitropoulos]], [[Dimitrios Loundras]], [[Filippos Karvelas]], and 15 others whose names are unknown.
The team placed third of the three teams in the [[parallel bars]] team event, earning a [[bronze medal]] (retroactively awarded by the [[International Olympic Committee]], as the awards at the first Olympic Games differed from the gold, silver, bronze format used later).
===Football trophies=== *[[Greek Super League|Panhellenic Football Championship]] **'''Winner (2):''' 1906, 1907
== Titles == *'''Men's Athletics''': **21 Greek Championships: ( 1901, 1910, 1920, 1925, 1926, 1927, 1928, 1930, 1931, 1937, 1938, 1939, 1940, 1946, 1947, 1948, 1949, 1950, 1951, 1953, 1954) **6 Greek Cross Country Championships: (1908, 1910, 1911, 1912, 1926, 1927) *'''Women's Athletics''': **1 Greek Championship: (1975) **1 Greek Cross Country Championship: (1982) *'''Shooting''': **1 Greek Championship: (1937) *'''Men's Boxing''': **2 Greek Championships: (1961, 1981) *'''Women's Boxing''': **1 Greek Championships: (2013) *'''Men's Greco-Roman Wrestling''': **35 Greek Championships, Men: (1936, 1937, 1938, 1939, 1940, 1946, 1947, 1948, 1949, 1950, 1951, 1952, 1958, 1960, 1962,[2] 1964, 1965, 1966, 1968, 1969, 1971, 1973, 1974, 1975, 1977, 1978, 1979, 1980, 1981, 1982[3], 1984, 1985, 1986, 1987, 1988) '''(record)''' *'''Men's Free Wrestling''': **4 Greek Championships, Men: (1958, 1959, 1960, 1966) *'''Judo''': **5 Greek Championships, Men: (1993, 1995, 1996, 1998, 2001)
==See also== *[[1905-06 Ethnikos G.S. Athens season]] *[[1906–07 Ethnikos G.S. Athens season]]
[[Category:Multi-sport clubs in Athens]] [[Category:Gymnastics at the 1896 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Athletics clubs in Greece]]

==Days of the month==
{{anchor|28_February_2011}}
===February 28, 2011 (Monday)===
====[[Cricket]]==== *[[2011 Cricket World Cup|World Cup]]: **[[2011 Cricket World Cup Group A|Group A]]: {{cr|ZIM}} 298/9 (50 overs); {{cr|CAN}} 123 (42.1 overs) in [[Vidarbha Cricket Association Stadium|Nagpur]], [[India]]. '''Zimbabwe win by 175 runs'''. ***Standings (after 2 matches): {{cr|PAK}}, {{cr|AUS}} 4 points, {{cr|SRI}}, {{cr|NZL}}, Zimbabwe 2, Canada, {{cr|KEN}} 0. **[[2011 Cricket World Cup Group B|Group B]]: {{cr|WIN}} 330/8 (50 overs); {{cr|NED}} 115 (31.3 overs; [[Kemar Roach]] 6/27) in [[Feroz Shah Kotla|New Delhi]], [[India]]. '''West Indies win by 215 runs'''. ***Roach bowls the sixth World Cup hat-trick, 28th in [[List of One Day International cricket hat-tricks|One Day Internationals]], and the second by a West Indian bowler, dismissing [[Pieter Seelaar]], [[Bernard Loots]] and [[Berend Westdijk]] to end the Dutch innings. ***Standings: {{cr|IND}}, {{cr|ENG}} 3 points (2 matches), West Indies 2 (2), {{cr|RSA}} 2 (1), {{cr|BAN}} 2 (2), {{cr|IRE}} 0 (1), Netherlands 0 (2).
====[[Cross-country skiing]]==== *[[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2011#Cross-country skiing|Nordic World Ski Championships]] in [[Holmenkollen National Arena|Oslo]], [[Norway]]: **[[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2011 – Women's 10 kilometre classical|Women's 10 km classical]]: {{gold1}} [[Marit Bjørgen]] {{cc3|NOR}} 27:39.3 {{silver2}} [[Justyna Kowalczyk]] {{cc3|POL}} 27:43.4 {{bronze3}} [[Aino-Kaisa Saarinen]] {{cc3|FIN}} 27:49.0 ***Bjørgen wins her third title of the championships and seventh of her career.
====[[Nordic combined]]==== *[[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2011#Nordic combined|Nordic World Ski Championships]] in [[Holmenkollen National Arena|Oslo]], [[Norway]]: **[[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2011 – Team normal hill/4 × 5 km|Team normal hill/4 x 5 km]]: {{gold1}} {{AUT}} ([[David Kreiner]], [[Bernhard Gruber]], [[Felix Gottwald]], [[Mario Stecher]]) 48:07.8 {{silver2}} {{GER}} ([[Johannes Rydzek]], [[Björn Kircheisen]], [[Tino Edelmann]], [[Eric Frenzel]]) 48:08.2 {{bronze3}} {{NOR}} ([[Jan Schmid]], [[Magnus Moan]], [[Mikko Kokslien]], [[Håvard Klemetsen]]) 48:48.4
{{anchor|27_February_2011}}

====[[Alpine skiing]]==== *[[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 2011|World Championships]] in [[Garmisch Classic|Garmisch-Partenkirchen]], [[Germany]]: **[[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 2011 – Men's Slalom|Men's Slalom]]: {{gold1}} [[Jean-Baptiste Grange]] {{cc3|FRA}} 1:41.72 (51.30 / 50.42) {{silver2}} [[Jens Byggmark]] {{cc3|SWE}} 1:42.15 (52.39 / 49.76) {{bronze3}} [[Manfred Mölgg]] {{cc3|ITA}} 1:42.33 (51.52 / 50.81) ***Grange becomes France's first male world champion since [[Michel Vion]] won the combined title in [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1982|1982]].
====[[Auto racing]]==== *[[2011 NASCAR Sprint Cup Series|Sprint Cup Series]]: **[[2011 Daytona 500|Daytona 500]] in [[Daytona International Speedway|Daytona Beach, Florida]]: (1) {{flagicon|Tennessee}} [[Trevor Bayne]] ([[Ford Motor Company|Ford]]; [[Wood Brothers Racing]]) (2) {{flagicon|Missouri}} [[Carl Edwards]] (Ford; [[Roush Fenway Racing]]) (3) {{flagicon|California}} [[David Gilliland]] (Ford; [[Front Row Motorsports]]) ***Bayne wins in only his second Sprint Cup start, and ties [[Jamie McMurray]]'s modern-era record from [[2002 NASCAR Winston Cup Series|2002]]. Bayne also becomes the youngest winner of the race, and the second-youngest winner in Sprint Cup history, at the age of {{Age in years and days|1991|02|19|2011|02|20}}.

====[[Ski jumping]]==== *[[Johan Remen Evensen]] {{cc3|NOR}} twice breaks the [[List of the longest ski jumps|world record for the longest ski jump]] during qualification for the [[2010–11 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup|World Cup]] event in [[Vikersundbakken|Vikersund, Norway]]. Evensen advances the record to 246.5 metres, 7.5 longer than the old mark set by teammate [[Bjørn Einar Romøren]] at [[Letalnica Bratov Gorišek|Planica]] in 2005.
====[[Tennis]]==== *[[Kim Clijsters]] {{cc3|BEL}} defeats [[Jelena Dokić]] {{cc3|AUS}} 6–3, 6–0 in the quarterfinals of [[2011 Open GDF Suez|Open GDF Suez]] in [[Paris]] to become the World no. 1 on the [[Women's Tennis Association|WTA]] rankings next Monday. She is the first ever mother at the top of the standings.

===February 10, 2011 (Thursday)===
====[[Basketball]]==== *{{flagicon|ISR}} [[Israeli Basketball State Cup 2010–11|Israeli State Cup]] Final in [[Nokia Arena, Tel Aviv|Tel Aviv]]: **'''[[Maccabi Tel Aviv B.C.|Maccabi Tel Aviv]]''' 106–70 [[Barak Netanya]] ***Maccabi Tel Aviv win the Cup for the second straight time and 38th overall. Four players, two of each team, are ejected following a brawl in the third period. The margin of victory is the third largest in Cup finals history. *[[2010–11 NBA season|NBA]] news: **[[Jerry Sloan]], [[List of Utah Jazz head coaches|head coach]] of the [[Utah Jazz]] since [[1988–89 Utah Jazz season|1988]] and the longest-tenured head coach in any of [[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada|North America's four major leagues]], announces his resignation effective immediately. Assistant [[Tyrone Corbin]] is named as Sloan's permanent replacement.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/news/story?id=6109031 |title=Utah Jazz coach Jerry Sloan resigns |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=February 10, 2011 |accessdate=February 10, 2011}}</ref> **In the [[2010–11 Boston Celtics season|Boston Celtics]]' 92–86 loss to the [[2010–11 Los Angeles Lakers season|Los Angeles Lakers]], the Celtics' [[Ray Allen]] becomes the [[National Basketball Association|NBA's]] all-time leader in career [[three-point field goal|three-pointers]], surpassing [[Reggie Miller]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://scores.espn.go.com/nba/recap?gameId=310210002 |title=Kobe Bryant has big second half to help Lakers rally by Celtics |author=Associated Press |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=February 10, 2011 |accessdate=February 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wR7Uz5ce?url=http://scores.espn.go.com/nba/recap?gameId=310210002 |archivedate=February 12, 2011 |df= }}</ref>

====[[Golf]]==== *[[Frank Chirkinian]], executive producer for [[CBS Sports]]' televised golf coverage from 1959 to 1996, is announced as part of the 2011 induction class of the [[World Golf Hall of Fame]]. He will be formally enshrined alongside five other inductees on May 9.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.worldgolfhalloffame.org/media/press_release.php?pr=hof73 |title=CBS television legend Frank Chirkinian joins World Golf Hall of Fame's 2011 Class |publisher=World Golf Hall of Fame |date=February 9, 2011 |accessdate=February 11, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604062241/http://www.worldgolfhalloffame.org/media/press_release.php?pr=hof73 |archivedate=June 4, 2011 |df= }}</ref>

====[[Basketball]]==== *The [[2010–11 Cleveland Cavaliers season|Cleveland Cavaliers]] set an [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] record for the longest losing streak in history, losing 99–96 to the [[2010–11 Dallas Mavericks season|Dallas Mavericks]] in [[American Airlines Center|Dallas]]. The Cavs' 25th straight loss breaks the record that [[Cleveland Cavaliers|the franchise]] set from 1982 to 1983.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nba/recap?gameId=310207006 |title=Mavericks run win streak to nine while extending Cavs' losing ways |author=Associated Press |publisher=''ESPN.com'' |date=February 7, 2011 |accessdate=February 8, 2011}}</ref>

''Talk 'N Text lead series 3–2.'' *[[Euroleague 2010–11#Top 16|Euroleague Top 16]], matchday 3: **[[Euroleague 2010–11 Top 16 Group H|Group H]]: ***[[Fenerbahçe Ülker]] {{flagicon|TUR}} 80–72 {{flagicon|LTU}} [[BC Žalgiris|Žalgiris Kaunas]] ***[[Olympiacos B.C.|Olympiacos Piraeus]] {{flagicon|GRE}} 77–62 {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Valencia BC|Power Electronics Valencia]] ****Standings (after 3 games): Fenerbahçe Ülker 3–0; Olympiacos Piraeus 2–1; Power Electronics Valencia 1–2; Žalgiris Kaunas 0–3.

'''Australia win by 2 wickets; lead 7-match series 5–1.''' ***Australia make their highest successful run chase, after England record their highest score against Australia.<ref>{{cite news|first=Phil|last=Dawkes|work=[[BBC Sport]]|publisher=[[BBC]]|date=February 2, 2011|accessdate=February 2, 2011|title=Aussie run-chase shocks England|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/england/9384646.stm}}</ref>

Deportes Tolima win 4–1 on points. **'''[[Grêmio Foot-Ball Porto Alegrense|Grêmio]]''' {{flagicon|BRA}} 3–1 (2–2) {{flagicon|URU}} [[Liverpool F.C. (Montevideo)|Liverpool]]. Grêmio win 4–1 on points.
====[[Freestyle skiing]]==== *[[2011 FIS Freestyle World Ski Championships|World Championships]] in [[Deer Valley]] and [[Park City Mountain Resort|Park City]], [[United States]]: **[[FIS Freestyle World Ski Championships 2011 – Men's moguls|Men's Moguls]]: {{gold1}} [[Guilbaut Colas]] {{cc3|FRA}} 26.26 points {{silver2}} [[Alexandre Bilodeau]] {{cc3|CAN}} 25.66 {{bronze3}} [[Mikaël Kingsbury]] {{cc3|CAN}} 25.57 ***Colas wins his first world title. **[[FIS Freestyle World Ski Championships 2011 – Women's moguls|Women's Moguls]]: {{gold1}} [[Jennifer Heil]] {{cc3|CAN}} 24.35 points {{silver2}} [[Hannah Kearney]] {{cc3|USA}} 24.31 {{bronze3}} [[Kristi Richards]] {{cc3|CAN}} 23.71 ***Heil wins her first moguls world title, and third overall.
====[[Ski jumping]]==== *[[2010–11 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup|World Cup]] in [[Vogtlandarena|Klingenthal]], [[Germany]]: **HS 140: {{gold1}} [[Kamil Stoch]] {{cc3|POL}} 264.6 points {{silver2}} [[Thomas Morgenstern]] {{cc3|AUT}} 264.0 {{bronze3}} [[Simon Ammann]] {{cc3|SUI}} 263.3 ***[[2010–11 FIS Ski Jumping World Cup#World Cup Standings|Standings]] (after 20 of 26 events): (1) Morgenstern 1514 points (2) Ammann 1073 (3) [[Andreas Kofler]] {{cc3|AUT}} 980
====[[Snooker]]==== *[[2011 German Masters|German Masters]] in [[Berlin]], [[Germany]], wild-card round: **'''[[Anthony Hamilton (snooker player)|Anthony Hamilton]]''' {{cc3|ENG}} 5–1 [[Pavel Leyk]] {{cc3|GER}} **'''[[Thanawat Thirapongpaiboon]]''' {{cc3|THA}} 5–3 [[Tomasz Skalski]] {{cc3|BEL}} **'''[[Jack Lisowski]]''' {{cc3|ENG}} 5–2 [[Luca Brecel]] {{cc3|BEL}} **'''[[Nigel Bond]]''' {{cc3|ENG}} 5–2 [[Stefan Kasper]] {{cc3|GER}} **'''[[Joe Swail]]''' {{cc3|NIR}} 5–0 [[Hans Blanckaert]] {{cc3|BEL}}

revision.text:
[[File:Salto de Cristiano Ronaldo.jpg|thumbnail|270px|[[Cristiano Ronaldo]] (9, white) heading the ball into the net for [[Real Madrid]] against [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] in the [[2009–10 UEFA Champions League group stage|2009–10 UEFA Champions League]].]] [[File:England Women's Vs USA (16365797348).jpg|thumbnail|270px|[[Abby Wambach]] heads the ball during a match against [[England women's national football team|England]] in February, 2015.]] '''Header'''<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.ldoceonline.com/Football-topic/header|title = head‧er|date = |access-date = 12 February 2016|website = ldoceonline|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> is a technique that is used in [[association football]] to control the ball using the head to pass, shoot or clear. This can be done by standing, jumping or diving position.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.soccerperformance.org/training/heading.htm|title = TECHNIQUE - HEADING|date = |access-date = 14 February 2016|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Header is a common technique and is used by players in almost every match.
In general, a [[Forward (association football)|forward]] uses a header to score a goal while a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] usually uses a header to prevent the scoring of a goal by the opponent. A header is the only option when the ball is in air, because of the rule that a player can’t make contact with the ball using their hands. Most header goals are scored as a result of a [[Cross (football)|cross]] or a [[Corner kick|corner]]. The [[playmaker]] passes the ball across the goal in the air, and the attacking player (either standing, jumping or diving position) strikes the ball with his head.<ref>{{cite web|title=Attacking Header|url=http://www.talkfootball.co.uk/guides/football_skills_attacking_header.html|work=Talkfootball|accessdate=14 February 2016}}</ref>
Footballers such as [[Fernando Torres]], [[Cristiano Ronaldo]], [[Andy Carroll]], [[Gareth Bale]], [[Javier Hernández|Javier Hernandez]], [[Sergio Ramos]], Peter Crouch, [[Ali Daei]] and [[Abby Wambach]]{{hsp}}<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2639471/Sergio-Ramos-header-important-Real-Madrid-Sportsmail-looks-10-headers.html |date =26 May 2014 |access-date = 12 February 2016|website = |work =Daily Mail |last = |first = |title =Sergio Ramos' Champions League final header was so important for Real Madrid... Sportsmail looks back at 10 of the best }}</ref> are players who are notable for their quality headers.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.sportskeeda.com/football/5-great-headers-in-recent-football|title = Great headers in recent football|date = |access-date = 12 February 2016|website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url = https://in.news.yahoo.com/10-best-headers-recent-football-092811554.html|title = Headers|date = |access-date = 12 February 2016|website = Yahoo|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Jackson|first1=Melanie|title=The Header Heard Round The World|url=http://www.espn.com/espnw/news-commentary/2015worldcup/article/13075090/abby-wambach-2011-header-heard-round-world|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=6 March 2017|date=June 15, 2015}}</ref>
==Health risks==
As with other high-impact sports such as [[Dementia pugilistica|boxing]] and [[Concussions in American football|American football]], concerns over player safety resulting in [[chronic traumatic encephalopathy]], due to the impact from both from the weight of the ball<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/does-heading-a-soccer-ball-cause-brain-damage/|title = Does Heading a Soccer Ball Cause Brain Damage?|date = 26 June 2014 |access-date = |website = Scientific American|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> and colliding with other players,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://jamanetwork.com/journals/jamapediatrics/fullarticle/2375128|title = An Evidence-Based Discussion of Heading the Ball and Concussions in High School Soccer|date = September 2015|access-date = |website = JAMA Pediatrics|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> [[United States Soccer Federation|U.S. Soccer]] has taken actions in "eliminating heading for children 10 and under, and limiting the amount of heading in practice for children between the ages of 11 and 13."<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.ussoccer.com/stories/2015/11/09/22/57/151109-ussoccer-provides-additional-information-about-upcoming-player-safety-campaign|title = U.S. Soccer Provides Additional Information About Upcoming Player Safety Campaign|date = 9 November 2015|access-date = |website = U.S. Soccer|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Volley (football)|Volley]] *[[Shooting (association football)|Shooting]] *[[Chip (association football)|Chip]] {{portal bar|Association football|Women's association football}}
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Association football tactics and skills]] [[Category:Association football terminology]]

{{Infobox sportsperson | honorific_prefix = | name = Ibragim Berkmanovich Samadov | honorific_suffix = | image = <!-- name.jpg --> | image_size = <!-- Use only when absolutely necessary --> | alt = | caption = | headercolor = <!-- Personal information --> | native_name = Ибрагим Беркманович Самадов | native_name_lang = | birth_name = | fullname = | nickname = | nationality = [[Chechen people|Chechen]] | ethnicity = | citizenship = USSR → Russian | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1968|7|18}} | birth_place = [[Pervomaysky, Russia|Pervomayskaya]], [[Groznensky District]], [[Chechen-Ingush Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Chechenskaya Respublika]], [[USSR]] | death_date = <!-- {{death date and age|death year|death month|death day|birth year|birth month|birth day}} --> | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = | residence = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = [[Olympic weightlifting]] | years_active = 1982-1992 | employer = | agent = | height = <!-- {{convert|}} (yyyy) --> | weight = {{convert|82.5|kg|lb|0}} | spouse = | life_partner = | other_interests = | website = <!-- {{URL|www.example.com}} --> | module = <!-- Sport --> | country = | sport = | position = | disability = | disability_class = | rank = | event = | collegeteam = | universityteam = | league = | league_type = | club = | team = | turnedpro = | partner = | former_partner = | coach = * Chingisov D.; * Lev Pekar; * Ibragim Kodzoev; * Adlan Magomedov. | retired = | coaching = | module2 = <!-- Achievements and titles --> | worlds = | regionals = | nationals = | olympics = | paralympics = | commonwealth = | highestranking = | pb = | <!-- Medal record --> | medaltemplates = {{MedalSport|[[Olympic weightlifting]]}} {{MedalCountry|{{USSR}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[World Weightlifting Championships]]}} {{MedalGold|[[1991 World Weightlifting Championships|1991 Donaueschingen]]|82.5 kg}} {{MedalCountry|{{RUS}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[European Weightlifting Championships]]}} {{MedalGold|[[1992 European Weightlifting Championships|1992 Szekszárd]]|82.5 kg}} | show-medals = | updated = 21 March 2015 }}
'''Ibragim Berkmanovich Samadov''' (''Ибрагим Беркманович Самадов'') born July 18, 1968 in [[Groznensky District|Pervomayskaya]], [[Chechenskaya Respublika]], [[USSR]] is a former [[Olympic weightlifting|Olympic weightlifter]]. In transition at the end of the Soviet Union, he represented the [[Unified Team at the 1992 Summer Olympics|Unified Team]] at the [[Weightlifting at the 1992 Summer Olympics – Men's 82.5 kg|1992 Olympics in the 82.5 kg division]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/sa/ibragim-samadov-1.html |title=Ibragim Samadov Bio, Stats, and Results | Olympics at |website=Sports-reference.com |date=1968-07-18 |accessdate=2017-03-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161203221536/http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/sa/ibragim-samadov-1.html |archivedate=2016-12-03 |df= }}</ref>
Samadov was the gold medalist at the [[1991 World Weightlifting Championships]], representing the Soviet Union with his superior [[clean and jerk]] evening his total weight with teammate Aleksandr Blyshchyk. In 1992, Altymurat Orazdurdiyev was the favorite, but was not selected for the Unified Team by coach and Russian national hero [[Vasily Alekseyev]] because Orazdurdiyev was from Turkmenistan, while Samadov was from Russia. Thus, Samadov was the new favorite.
The Olympic competition was the closest in history, with all three medalists tied with the same weight lifted. The first tiebreaker was the athlete's body weight and Samadov was .05 kg heavier, pushing him to the bronze medal position. The second tie breaker was based on which athlete had lifted their weight first and Samadov would have bested eventual winner, [[Albania]]n born ethnic [[Greeks|Greek]] [[Pyrros Dimas]] by lifting his [[Snatch (weightlifting)|snatch]] on his second lift to Dimas' third.
At the medal ceremony, Samadov refused to lean forward to accept his medal, instead taking it in his hand, before he dropped it to the podium and walked away to very loud boos.
The [[International Olympic Committee]] disqualified Samadov and banned him for life. Samadov apologized the following day but the medal was not awarded, to him or to fourth place [[Chon Chol-Ho]] because the disqualification did not happen during the award ceremony.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/summer/1992/WLT/mens-light-heavyweight.html |title=Weightlifting at the 1992 Barcelona Summer Games: Men's Light-Heavyweight | Olympics at |website=Sports-reference.com |date=1992-08-03 |accessdate=2017-03-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202210155/http://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/summer/1992/WLT/mens-light-heavyweight.html |archivedate=2017-02-02 |df= }}</ref> The IOC also did not accept his apology, and he was also banned for life by weightlifting commissioner [[Gottfried Schoedl]].
He was ineligible for the [[Weightlifting Hall of Fame]], since making a medal ceremony protest was a crime to the entire Olympic Games.
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Infobox national sports federations |assocname= Icelandic Handball Association
''{{lang-is|Handknattleikssamband Íslands}}'' |abbrev= HSÍ |logo= |logosize= 250px |countryflag= Iceland |iocnation= Iceland (ISL) |url= http://hsi.is |sport= [[Handball]] |othersport1= [[Beach Handball]] |othersport2= [[Wheelchair Handball]] |historytitle=HISTORY |precedingorganisationsname= |yearfounded= {{Start date and age|1957|06|11|df=y}} |formernames= |demographicstitle=DEMOGRAPHICS |noofclubs= |noofaffclubs= |membershipsize= |participationlevels= |affliationstitle=AFFLIATIONS |IF = [[International Handball Federation]] | IF_abbr = IHF | IF_joined = {{Start date and age|1984| | |df=y}} |nationalolympiccom= [[National Olympic and Sports Association of Iceland]] |continentalassoc= [[European Handball Federation]] |nocyearjoined= |otheraff2= |otheraff3= |otheraff4= |otheraff5= |electedtitle= GOVERNING BODY |patron= |president= Mr. [[Guðmundur B. Ólafsson]] {{flagicon|ISL}}{{cite web|title=Stjórn HSÍ|url=http://www.hsi.is/um-hsi/almennt-um-hsi/stjorn/|publisher=Icelandic Handball Association|accessdate=27 January 2014|language=Icelandic}} |sectitle= HEADQUARTERS |address1= Engjavegur 6, 104 [[Reykjavík]] |country= [[Iceland]] |chiefexec= Mr. [[Róbert Geir Gíslason]] {{flagicon|ISL}} |secretarygeneral= Mr. [[Róbert Geir Gíslason]] {{flagicon|ISL}} |financetitle=FINANCE |companystatus= |operatingincome= |sponsors= [[Coca-Cola]]
[[Icelandair]]
[[Uhlsport]]
[[Arion Bank]]
[[Olís]]
[[Samskip]] }} The '''Icelandic Handball Association''' ({{lang-is|Handknattleikssamband Íslands}} or ''HSÍ'') is the national [[sport governing body|governing body]] for [[team handball|handball]] in [[Iceland]]. It is based in [[Reykjavík]]. == Club handball == The federation organizes the national handball leagues for both [[N1 deildin|men]] and women club teams and the Icelandic cup for men and women. == International handball == Iceland was the host of the [[1995 World Men's Handball Championship]]. ===The men's team=== The [[Iceland national handball team|men's team]] has appeared frequently in large tournaments in recent decades. Their best overall result is the silver medal at the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]. Their best result in the [[IHF World Men's Handball Championship|world championship]] is 5th place in [[1997 World Men's Handball Championship|1997]]. They have made it to the semi finals of the [[European Men's Handball Championship]] twice, winning the bronze medal in [[2010 European Men's Handball Championship|2010]]. Head coach for the men's national team is [[Aron Kristjánsson]].{{cite web|title=A landslið karla|url=http://www.hsi.is/default.aspx?PageID=8357cd50-73c2-11e3-9eb6-005056864800|publisher=Icelandic handball association|accessdate=27 January 2014|language=Icelandic}} ===The women's team=== The [[Iceland women's national handball team|women's team]] has just recently started to appear in large tournaments. They have made it to the [[IHF World Women's Handball Championship|world championship]] once, finishing in 12th place in [[2011 World Women's Handball Championship|2011]]. They have appeared in the [[European Women's Handball Championship|European championship]] twice, finishing in 15th place in both [[2010 European Women's Handball Championship|2010]] and [[2012 European Women's Handball Championship|2012]]. The team has never made it to the [[Olympic games]]. Head coach for the women's national team is [[Ágúst Þór Jóhannsson]].{{cite web|title=A landslið kvenna|url=http://www.hsi.is/default.aspx?PageID=4a940b40-73c3-11e3-9eb6-005056864800|publisher=Icelandic Handball Association|accessdate=27 January 2014|language=Icelandic}} == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * {{Official website}} {{is icon}} {{Sports governing bodies in Iceland}} {{National members of the European Handball Federation}} {{National Members of the International Handball Federation}} [[Category:Handball in Iceland]] [[Category:European Handball Federation|Iceland]] [[Category:Sports governing bodies in Iceland]] {{sport-org-stub}} {{Iceland-sport-stub}}

{{Motorsport venue | Name = NOLA Motorsports Park | Nicknames = | Time = [[UTC]][[UTC-6|-6]] (UTC[[UTC-5|-5]] [[Daylight saving time|DST]]) | Location = 11075 Nicolle Boulevard, [[Avondale, Louisiana|Avondale]], [[Louisiana]] 70094 | Coordinates = {{coord|29|53|1|N|90|11|52|W|type:landmark_region:US-LA|display=inline,title}} | Image = NOLA Motorsports Park IndyCar Series.png | Image_caption = | Capacity = | Owner = Laney Chouest | Operator = | Broke_ground = December 2009 | Opened = 2011 | Closed = | Construction_cost= $62 million | Architect = [[Alan Wilson (motorsport)|Alan Wilson]] | Former_names = | Events = [[2012 AMA Pro American Superbike Championship season#Calendar|Triumph Big Kahuna New Orleans]] (2012)
[[2014 U.S. F2000 Winterfest#Race calendar and results|Cooper Tires WinterFest]] (2014)
[[Indy Grand Prix of Louisiana]] (2015) | Miles_first = True | Layout1 = Full Track | Surface = Asphalt | Length_km = 8.64 | Length_mi = 5.37 | Turns = 27 | Banking = | Record_time = | Record_driver = | Record_team = | Record_year = | Record_class = | Layout2 = North Track | Surface2 = Asphalt | Length_km2 = 4.42 | Length_mi2 = 2.75 | Turns2 = 16 | Banking2 = | Record_time2 = | Record_driver2 = | Record_team2 = | Record_year2 = | Record_class2 = | Layout3 = South Track | Surface3 = Asphalt | Length_km3 = 4.33 | Length_mi3 = 2.69 | Turns3 = 11 | Banking3 = | Record_time3 = | Record_driver3 = | Record_team3 = | Record_year3 = | Record_class3 = }} '''NOLA Motorsports Park''' is a road [[race track]] in [[Avondale, Louisiana]], approximately twenty minutes from downtown [[New Orleans]]. The [[kart racing|kart]] circuit and North Track circuits opened in Q4 2011. Future plans include completion of a South Track. When linked with the North Track will form a five-mile course, making it the longest race track in North America.{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/business/index.ssf/2012/01/west_bank_getting_750-acre_60.html |title=Avondale getting 750-acre, $60 million racetrack |publisher=The Times-Picayune |author=Paul Rioux |date=2012-01-30 |accessdate=2012-02-15}} ==Design== NOLA Motorsports Park was designed by [[Alan Wilson (motorsport)|Alan Wilson]], whose other designs include [[Utah Motorsports Campus]] and [[Barber Motorsports Park]]. In addition to the two international standard race tracks, the facility also features three karting tracks, full service seven acre kart center, paddock, on-site speed shop, clubhouse, eight acre autocross pad, single lane dragstrip and luxury villas for residents.{{cite web |url=http://www.nolamotor.com/facility-features/ |title=Facility Features |publisher=nolamotor.com/ |date= |accessdate=2012-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303132516/http://www.nolamotor.com/facility-features/ |archivedate=2012-03-03 |df= }} The park has also been designed with forward thinking electronic systems including over 100 miles of fiber optics and the latest timing and scoring equipment to allow for accurate timing.{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/blog/playbook/tech/post/_/id/2537/nola-motorsports-is-racings-most-high-tech-track |title=NOLA Motorsports innovates with new track |publisher=ESPN The Magazine |author=Alejandro de los Rios |date=2012-10-02 |accessdate=2012-10-02}} ==Major events== ;2012 * [[2012 AMA Pro American Superbike Championship season#Calendar|Triumph Big Kahuna New Orleans]]: [[American Motorcyclist Association#AMA Pro Racing|AMA Pro Racing]] [[AMA Superbike Championship|Superbike Championship]] (season finale), October 5–7{{cite web|url=http://www.m1powersports.com/blog/nola-motorsports-park-announces-the-big-kahuna-new-orleans-ama-pro-racing-season-finale/ |title=NOLA Motorsports Park announces The Big Kahuna New Orleans AMA Pro Racing Season Finale |publisher=m1powersports.com/ |date=2012-12-29 |accessdate=2012-02-15}} ;2014 * [[2014 U.S. F2000 Winterfest#Race calendar and results|Cooper Tires WinterFest]]: [[Indy Lights]], [[Formula Mazda#New car – Pro Formula Mazda|Pro Formula Mazda]], [[F2000 Championship Series|F2000]], February 21–22{{cite web|url=http://www.nola.com/sports/index.ssf/2014/05/indycar_commits_to_new_orleans.html|title=IndyCar commits to New Orleans race at NOLA Motorsports Park in 2015|publisher=The Times-Picayune/nola.com|date=2014-05-04 |accessdate=2014-05-27}} ;2015 * [[Indy Grand Prix of Louisiana]]: [[IndyCar Series]], April 10–12{{cite web|url=http://www.indycar.com/News/2014/08/8-27-NOLA-race-debuts-on-2015-schedule|title=IndyCar commits to New Orleans race at NOLA Motorsports Park in 2015|publisher=The Times-Picayune/nola.com|date=2014-05-04 |accessdate=2014-05-27}} ==Maps== Image:NOLA Motorsports Park - North C.jpg|North Course C ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Official|http://www.nolamotor.com/}} {{Indy Racing League}} {{Pro Mazda Championship race venues}} {{USF2000 National Championship race venues}} {{Trans-Am tracks}} {{IMSA Prototype Challenge racetracks}} {{Global MX-5 Cup tracks}} {{F3 Americas Championship circuits}} [[Category:Motorsport venues in Louisiana]] [[Category:Motorsport in New Orleans]] [[Category:IndyCar Series tracks]] {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = North Charleston Coliseum | nickname = "Casa del Ray" "Hockeyharbor, USA" | image = [[File:North Charleston Coliseum Aug2010.jpg|250px]] | location = 5001 Coliseum Drive
[[North Charleston, South Carolina|North Charleston, SC]] 29418 | coordinates = {{coord|32.8656|-80.0224|type:landmark_region:US-SC|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = April 29, 1991 | opened = January 29, 1993 | renovated = 2010-2012 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[North Charleston, South Carolina|City of North Charleston]] | operator = [[SMG (property management)|SMG]] | surface = Multi-surface | construction_cost = [[United States dollar|$]]25 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|25000000|1993}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}})
2010-12 renovations: $21 million
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|21000000|2012}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | former_names = | architect = Odell Associates | project_manager = | structural engineer = [[Geiger Engineers]]{{cite web |title=Stephen P. Emery, P.E.|url=http://www.geigerengineers.com/stephen-emery|publisher=Geiger Engineers|accessdate=October 23, 2011}} | services engineer = Henderson Engineers, Inc.{{cite web |title=Sports/Recreation|url=http://www.hei-eng.com/Portfolio/SportsRecreation|publisher=Henderson Engineers, Inc.|accessdate=January 16, 2014}} | general_contractor = [[Lend Lease Project Management & Construction|McDevitt & Street Co.]] | tenants = [[South Carolina Stingrays]] ([[ECHL]]) (1993–present)
[[Charleston Southern Buccaneers]] ([[NCAA]]) (1993–present)
[[Charleston Swamp Foxes]] ([[AF2]]) (2000–2003)
[[Florida Flame|Charleston Lowgators]] ([[NBA G League|NBDL]]) (2001–2004)
[[Carolina Sandsharks]] ([[National Indoor Football League|NIFL]]) (2006) | seating_capacity = 13,295 (center-stage events)
8,805-12,645 (end-stage events)
11,475 (basketball)
10,537 (hockey, football)
5,970 (half-house events) }} The '''North Charleston Coliseum''' is a 14,000-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[North Charleston, South Carolina]]. It is part of the North Charleston Convention Center Complex, which also includes a Performing Arts Center, and is owned by the City of North Charleston and managed by [[SMG (property management)|SMG]]. The Coliseum was built in 1993 (the Performing Arts Center and Convention Center opened in 1999), and is located on the access road to the [[Charleston International Airport]]. The Coliseum is home to the [[ECHL]]'s [[South Carolina Stingrays]] professional ice hockey team and serves as an alternate home for the [[Charleston Southern University]] basketball team. It is the area's primary venue for concerts and other major indoor events expected to draw large crowds. The Coliseum is currently undergoing an expansion project intended to increase concourse space, provide additional points of sale, and create venues for banquets, receptions, and other smaller-scale events. The arena contains 9,875 permanent seats, including 7,175 in the upper deck, and 1,646 riser seats. ==Tenants== The Coliseum is the current home of the [[South Carolina Stingrays]], a minor league professional [[ice hockey]] team that plays in the [[ECHL]]. When construction first began on the arena there were no plans to include ice-making equipment. However, after an ECHL franchise application for the city of North Charleston had been pre-approved by the league in April 1992, the city council approved the funds required for the installation of an ice surface into the building that was already well under construction.{{cite book| first=Jon C.|last=Scott| title=Hockey Night in Dixie: Minor Pro Hockey in the American South| year=2006| publisher=Heritage House Publishing Company Ltd.| pages=68–102| isbn=1-894974-21-2}} The Stingrays began play there for the [[1993–94 ECHL season]]. It is the alternate home arena for the [[Charleston Southern University]] basketball team. Typically, Charleston Southern University uses the Coliseum for non-conference games that draw audiences greater than their home arena's 798-seat capacity, such as cross-town rivals College of Charleston and The Citadel. Furthermore, its size allows them to play major conference teams such as Virginia Tech at home (some major conference arenas do not seat 10,000). In addition, The North Charleston Coliseum has hosted the [[Big South Conference]] (1993–94) and the [[Southern Conference]] basketball tournaments. The Coliseum has previously hosted [[arena football|arena]] and [[Indoor American football|indoor football]] teams, as well as a [[National Basketball Development League]] team, as well as an all female production of Ben Hur that drew several noise and indecency complaints. ==Events== In addition to sporting events, the arena hosts concerts, comedy shows and various other events. The Coliseum has served as the venue for several televised events, to include [[In Your House 8: Beware of Dog]] pay-per-view after the Florence Civic Center's infrastructure failed (1996), [[WCW Uncensored (1997)]], [[Shania Twain]] (2004), [[WWE Raw]] (2002, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2013, 2015), [[Professional Bull Riders|PBR]] [[Built Ford Tough Series]] (2006), ''[[Wheel of Fortune (U.S. game show)|Wheel of Fortune]]'' (2006), and ''[[American Idol]]'' (2007, 2011) and ''[[The X Factor (U.S. TV series)|The X Factor]]'' (2013) auditions. Other major concerts and events have included [[Kiss (band)|KISS]] playing their final show with the original lineup (2000), [[Oprah Winfrey]] (2006), [[Walking with Dinosaurs]] (2008), a [[CNN]] [[Republican Party presidential debates, 2012|Presidential Debate]] (2012), a [[Fox Business]] [[Republican Party presidential debates, 2016|Presidential Debate]] (2016), [[Kid Rock]] (2008, 2011), [[Taylor Swift]] (2009), [[The Dave Matthews Band]] (in 1996, and since 2005), [[Kenny Chesney]] (2011), [[Jay-Z]] (2013), [[Brad Paisley]] (2011, 2014), [[Prince (musician)|Prince]] (2011).{{cite news| title=Prince Dazzles 12,000 at Coliseum| first=Devin| last=Grant| url=http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch11/0311/arc033111720735.shtml| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=March 31, 2011| accessdate=June 1, 2011}} and [[Trans-Siberian Orchestra]]'s winter concerts and [[Beethoven's Last Night]] shows (2004-2012). The Coliseum hosted [[Metallica]] in '93 [[Nowhere Else to Roam]] Tour, Columbia's [[Hootie & the Blowfish]] with Greenville's [[Edwin McCain]] in '95, Gainesville's [[Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers]] in '95, Athens GA's [[R.E.M.]] in '95, [[Green Day]] in '95, Macon GA's [[Allman Brothers Band]] in '96, [[Pearl Jam]] in '96, [[Stone Temple Pilots]] in '97, [[Jay-Z]] in '99, and [[N'SYNC]] in 2000. ==History== ===Planning and construction=== Planning for the coliseum began in 1985, when a city-sponsored study determined that the city could support a venue seating 10,000-plus people. In October of that year, the McNair Realty and Development company of [[Greenville, South Carolina]], who owned the 400-acre Centre Pointe development tract, donated 30 acres of that land valued at approximately $100,000 an acre to the city for construction of the coliseum.{{cite news |title=Land Donated for North Charleston Coliseum| agency=[[Associated Press]]| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=T0ktAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xcAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5423,5856767&dq=north-charleston-coliseum&hl=en| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=October 14, 1985| accessdate=June 9, 2011}} The coliseum was originally planned to be part of a redevelopment dubbed "City Center," which was to include the coliseum, a convention center, a performing arts center, a transportation hub, a library, an art gallery and museum, an arts school, parking garages, and scenic park areas, and was to have been completed by 2000.{{cite news |title=N. Charleston Works for New Identity| first=Rick| last=Nelson| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6mFJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QAoNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3868,3302257&dq=north-charleston-coliseum&hl=en| newspaper=The Post and Courier|location=Charleston, SC| date=December 25, 1988| accessdate=June 10, 2011}} As of June 2011, only the coliseum, convention center, and performing arts center have been completed. In September 1988, the city considered five architectural firms for design and supervision of the coliseum's construction,{{cite news |title=Architects Hope to Create N. Chas Image| first=Jim| last=Parker| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_6lbAAAAIBAJ&sjid=4FENAAAAIBAJ&pg=1726,2081899&dq=north-charleston-coliseum&hl=en|newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=September 5, 1988| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} eventually settling on Odell Associates, Inc.{{cite news |title=Charlotte Firm Gets Contract for Coliseum| first=Rick| last=Nelson|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=7VNSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rzYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3131,4613212&dq=north-charleston-coliseum&hl=en| newspaper=The Post and Courier|location=Charleston, SC| date=February 1, 1991| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} City Council approved a $25 million budget for design and construction of the coliseum and by February 1991 accepted a $19.8 million bid for the construction contract by [[Lend Lease Project Management & Construction|McDevitt and Street Co.]] of [[Charlotte, North Carolina]]. Construction began on April 29, 1991, with an estimated completion time of 20 months.{{cite news | title=S.C.'s Largest Coliseum Scheduled to Be Built| agency=[[Associated Press]]| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=nl4tAAAAIBAJ&sjid=JNoFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4869,6663805&dq=north+charleston+coliseum+break+ground&hl=en| newspaper=[[The Post and Courier]]| location=Charleston, SC| date=April 29, 1991| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} In September 1992, the City Council approved $879,000 to fund installation of an ice rink in the coliseum, which at that time was scheduled for completion by December 26 of that year.{{cite news |title=North Charleston Funds Ice Rink| first=Fred| last=Rigsbee| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oVRSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=wDYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6042,346752&dq=north+charleston+coliseum+ice+rink&hl=en| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=September 3, 1992| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} The [[ECHL]] Board of Governors met in November 1992 to vote on bringing a hockey franchise (whose application had been pre-approved that April) to the Charleston area.{{cite news |title=ECHL Voting on Charleston Hockey Franchise Coming Up|first=Keith|last=Namm|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=3DhSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=sDYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=5847,85333&dq=north+charleston+coliseum+ice+rink&hl=en| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=November 16, 1992| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} At that meeting, the league approved creation of the [[South Carolina Stingrays|expansion franchise]] for the [[1993–94 ECHL season]], giving the coliseum its first professional sports team as a tenant.{{cite news |title=Minnesota's Quinn Won't Be Charged| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yzEfAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Dc8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=3500,2844171&dq=charleston+hockey+franchise&hl=en| newspaper=[[Spartanburg Herald-Journal]]| date=November 25, 1992| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} ===Grand opening=== The coliseum opened its doors on January 29, 1993 to a capacity crowd with its first event, the World Cup Figure Skating Champions ice skating exhibition.{{cite news |title=Coliseum Opens Doors on a New Era| first1=David| last1=MacDougall| first2=Fred| last2=Rigsbee| url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sFNSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=rDYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=3947,4525653&dq=north+charleston+coliseum+grand+opening&hl=en| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=January 30, 1993| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} The opening night was plagued by parking issues that resulted in traffic congestion on local roads and up to an hour delay in clearing the parking lots following the show.{{cite news |title=Coliseum Puts Parking on Fast Track|first=Fred|last=Rigsbee|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=hzxSAAAAIBAJ&sjid=pzYNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1960,239533&dq=north+charleston+coliseum+1993+parking&hl=en| newspaper=The Post and Courier|location=Charleston, SC| date=February 2, 1993| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} The following night saw another sellout crowd for a concert featuring [[country music]] star [[Alan Jackson]], for which the traffic problems were reduced due to early arrivals and improved traffic direction. The city expedited the expansion of available parking spaces from 4,000 to 5,030 soon after. ===Accident=== On November 10, 1997, the 5-ton coliseum scoreboard dropped while it was being lowered, landing on and killing Billie Wayne Garrett, a [[rodeo]] volunteer from [[Columbia, South Carolina]]. Coliseum officials believed the issue was with the board's hoisting mechanism, which was manufactured by a New Jersey company that had recently experienced hoist failures in two of its mechanisms, one resulting in a scoreboard dropping to the floor.{{cite news |title=Board Fell on Descent| first1=Edward| last1=Fennell| first2=Amy J.| last2=Wise| url=http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch97/1197/arc1112175572.shtml| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=November 12, 1997| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} The fall also caused a crack in the coliseum floor,{{cite news |title=Coliseum Flooring Cracked| first=Amy| last=Wise| url=http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch97/1197/arc1114177221.shtml| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=November 14, 1997| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} but it was repaired and no damage was found to have been done to the piping system that makes ice for the coliseum floor.{{cite news |title=Ice Able to Form on Coliseum Floor|first=Rick|last=Nelson|url=http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch97/1197/arc1118175381.shtml| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=November 18, 1997| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} Garrett's family filed a wrongful death lawsuit against the company that manufactured the scoreboard, the company that had recently inspected and passed the scoreboard, and Ogden Entertainment, the coliseum's managing company.{{cite news |title=Family Files Suit Over Falling Scoreboard Death| first=Amy| last=Wise| url=http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch98/0198/arc0128181755.shtml| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=January 28, 1998| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} The lawsuit was settled for $3.5 million.{{cite news | title=Scoreboard Suit Settled for $3.5M| first=Edward| last=Fennell| url=http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch98/0998/arc0912202220.shtml| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=September 12, 1998| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} An upgraded scoreboard featuring improved video panels and a safer hoisting setup was installed in October 1999.{{cite news |title=Coliseum Gets Flashier Board| first=Nadine| last=Parks| url=http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch99/1099/arc1014241356.shtml| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=October 14, 1999| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} This scoreboard was replaced in 2012 by another video scoreboard, part of a $21 million renovation that saw the addition of two food courts, the largest of which is the 7,400-square-foot Montague Terrace, as well as a new ticket office and upgrades to eight luxury suites. ===New management=== In August 2000, Ogden Entertainment—which had managed the coliseum since its opening in 1993—was purchased by [[Aramark]]. Aramark urged city officials to transfer management of the coliseum to SMG, of which Aramark was a half owner at the time, in an effort to leverage SMG's entertainment industry connections to bring more concerts to the area.{{cite news |title=Coliseum Manager is Sold| first=Ben| last=Brazil| url=http://archives.postandcourier.com/archive/arch00/0800/arc0826266654.shtml| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=August 26, 2000| accessdate=June 13, 2011}} In an effort to bolster attendance at the coliseum, which had been operating at a loss for two years, SMG took over management of the coliseum in late 2001, agreeing to construct a large freestanding marquee visible from [[Interstate 526]] as part of the management contract.{{cite news |title=Coliseum Hopes Massive Marquee Will Help Draw Crowds| first=James| last=Scott|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=48ZJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=_woNAAAAIBAJ&pg=6261,2626263&dq=north+charleston+coliseum+manager&hl=en| newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=December 22, 2001|accessdate=June 13, 2011}} ===Expansion=== An ambitious expansion project was approved for financing by the city of North Charleston in 2009. The expansion consists of extensions built onto the Coliseum's north and south entrances, increasing concourse space by {{convert|20000|sqft|m2}} and adding up to 40 additional points of sale for concessions. The expansion will allow for renovation of existing suites and upgrades to the Coliseum's sound system, spotlights, and rigging bridges. Construction on the south side extension, dubbed Montague Terrace, commenced in August 2010 with a planned completion date of October 2011.{{cite news |title=Overhaul Not Expected to Affect Coliseum Events| first=Schuyler| last=Kropf| url=http://www.postandcourier.com/news/2010/aug/15/overhaul-not-expected-to-affect-coliseum-events/|newspaper=The Post and Courier| location=Charleston, SC| date=August 15, 2010| accessdate=May 31, 2011}} Construction of the north side extension was completed in 2012. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I basketball arenas]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.northcharlestoncoliseumpac.com/ North Charleston Coliseum web site] *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7qt2nrd916s Video of proposed Coliseum expansion] {{ECHL Arenas|state=collapsed}} {{Charleston Southern Buccaneers men's basketball navbox}} {{Big South Conference basketball venue navbox}} {{Music venues of South Carolina}} [[Category:1993 establishments in South Carolina]] [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Basketball venues in South Carolina]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in North Charleston, South Carolina]] [[Category:Charleston Lowgators]] [[Category:Charleston Southern Buccaneers men's basketball]] [[Category:College basketball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Ice hockey venues in South Carolina]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in South Carolina]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in the United States]] [[Category:NBA G League arenas]] [[Category:Professional wrestling venues in the United States]] [[Category:South Carolina Stingrays]] [[Category:Sports venues in Charleston, South Carolina]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1993]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Multiple issues| {{One source|date=April 2015}} {{Refimprove|date=April 2015}} }}
{{Portal|Cricket}} The '''result''' in a game of [[cricket]] may be a "win" for one of the two teams playing, a "draw" or a "tie". In the case of a [[one-day cricket|limited overs game]], the game can also end with "no result". Which of these results applies, and how the result is expressed, is governed by Law 16 of the [[laws of cricket]].<ref name="law 16">{{cite web |url=https://www.lords.org/mcc/laws-of-cricket/laws/law-16-the-result/ |title=Law 16 – The result |publisher=MCC |accessdate=29 June 2017}}</ref>
==Win and loss== The result of a match is a "win" when one side scores more [[run (cricket)|runs]] than the opposing side and all the [[innings]] of the team that has fewer runs have been completed.<ref name="law 16" /> The side scoring more runs has "won" the game, and the side scoring fewer has "lost". If the match ends without all the innings being completed, the result may be a draw or no result.
==Tie== {{main|List of tied first-class cricket matches}} The result of a match is a "tie" when the scores are equal at the conclusion of play, but only if the side batting last has completed its innings (i.e. all innings are completed, or, in [[One-day cricket|limited-overs cricket]], the set number of [[Over (cricket)|overs]] has been played or play is terminally stopped by weather or bad light).<ref name="law 16" />
This is unusual in [[Test cricket]]: only two [[tied Test]]s have ever occurred.
In some forms of [[one-day cricket]], such as [[Twenty20]], a [[Super Over]] or a [[bowl-out]] is used as a tiebreaker to decide a result that would otherwise be a tie. In such cases, the result of the match is recorded in official statistics as Tie+W or Tie+L to indicate matches tied and then won or lost in the tiebreaker.
==Draw== <!-- This section is linked from [[Cricket]] --> The result of a match is a "draw" if a match is concluded, as defined in Law 16, without being a win or a tie.<ref name="law 16" /> A draw therefore occurs when the one or both of the teams have not completed their innings by the scheduled end of play. In matches where the number of overs is not limited, therefore, a team unable to win may be able to 'save the draw' by either avoiding being all-out if they are batting (i.e. by having two or more batsmen left at the end of play who are 'not out'), or, if bowling, by slowing down the scoring of the batting team. The match is then drawn regardless of the total of runs accumulated by either side.
== No result== A "no result" is recorded if a limited over match which has been started cannot be completed. This would usually occur if weather or light interrupts play. The result is effectively the same as a draw.
Limited overs cricket formats require that each team can bat for a sufficient number of overs in order for a result to be possible. As of 2016 this stands at 20 overs in [[One Day International]] cricket and five overs in [[Twenty20]] cricket. If each team is able to face at least this number of overs a result is possible and can be calculated using the [[Duckworth–Lewis method]] or other competition rules.
==Abandoned== A match can be "abandoned" if weather or other conditions prevent any play from occurring at all. If the bowler of the first over of play has not started his/her runup when the officials decide to abandon play then the result is termed 'abandoned without a ball being bowled'. Such a game is not included in official [[cricket statistics|statistical records]].
Before July 2004, the same result occurred if the toss had been taken but the match was abandoned before a ball was bowled. Since 2004, the [[International Cricket Council]] for International matches has decreed that a match where the toss takes place but which is abandoned without a ball being bowled is either a draw or (for a limited-overs match) a no result. Such games are now included in statistical records, counting, for example, as a game played by the teams and nominated players.<ref name="Rediff">{{cite web | url=http://www.rediff.com/cricket/2004/jul/09toss1.htm | title=Toss to signify start of a match | publisher=[[Rediff.com]] | date=9 July 2004 | accessdate=4 April 2015}}</ref>
==Awarded== The [[Umpire (cricket)|umpires]] also have the power to "award" a match to one side where the other side either concedes defeat or in the opinion of the umpires refuses to play, in which case the game can be deemed to have been forfeited by the side in question.<ref name="law 16" /> (Note that this is not the same as the (voluntary) [[Declaration and forfeiture|forfeiture]] of an innings under Law 15.) This power is very rarely used. Before this rule was introduced there had been cases in the international arena where one team has refused to play, or deliberately stopped playing for a while. One notable incident was when [[Sri Lankan cricket team|Sri Lanka]] temporarily stopped play against [[English cricket team|England]] when [[Muttiah Muralitharan]] was called for [[throwing (cricket)|throwing]] by umpire [[Darrell Hair]].
The only time that a [[Test cricket|Test match]] has been won in this manner is when umpires [[Darrell Hair]] and [[Billy Doctrove]] awarded [[English cricket team|England]] the [[Pakistani cricket team in England in 2006#Fourth Test .2817–20 August.29|Fourth Test]] against [[Pakistani cricket team|Pakistan]] on 20 August 2006 after Pakistan refused to take the field at the scheduled time after tea on the fourth day. This was because Hair alleged that Pakistani bowlers tampered with the ball. He did not name a player involved in the incident. Later during the ICC general body meeting in 2008, the result was changed to "match drawn", and then in February 2009 changed back to an England win.<ref name="award2009">{{cite news|title=Cricket: England awarded Oval Test 'win' against Pakistan|url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2009/feb/01/england-pakistan-oval|accessdate=8 January 2018|work=The Guardian|date=1 February 2009}}</ref>
==Conceded== Law 16 allows a team to concede a match. This seldom happens, but it covers the situation where the scoreboard has in good faith displayed an incorrect score which is accepted by the "losing" team, who leave the field, thereby conceding the match to the opposition.
==Statement of result== {{See also|Scoring (cricket)}} The '''result''' of a cricket match is stated in several ways.
If the side batting last wins the match without losing all its [[wicket]]s, the result shall be stated as a win by the number of wickets still then to fall. For example, in a single-innings match, if Team A bat first and make 200 runs, then Team B make 201 after losing four wickets out of ten, Team B is said to have "won by six wickets", regardless of how many batsmen Team A lost during their innings.
If the side fielding last wins the match, the result shall be stated as a win by runs. For instance, if Team A bat first and make 200 runs, but Team B make only 192, Team A is said to have "won by eight runs".
If the side batting last has lost all its wickets, but as the result of an award of 5 penalty runs at the end of the match has scored a total of runs in excess of the total scored by the opposing side, the result shall be stated as a win to that side by penalty runs.
In a two-innings match, if the number of runs scored in its first innings by the side due to bat last is greater than the total runs scored by the opposition in both its innings, the result is stated as a win by an innings and number of runs short. Here "due to bat last" includes a team who batted first, but forced their opponent to [[Follow-on|follow on]]. If Team A bat first and make 200 runs in their first innings, Team B make 300 runs in their first innings, and Team A only make 95 runs in their second innings, Team B is said to have "won by an innings and five runs".
If the match is decided by one side conceding defeat or refusing to play, the result shall be stated as "Match Conceded" or "Match Awarded".
If a match is unfinished when time expires, the result is a "draw" (this does not apply to limited overs cricket, where this is considered to be "no result"). If all innings of both teams are completed (either because all batsmen have been dismissed or one/more innings are completed by way of a declaration) ''and'' the totals are exactly equal, the match is a "tie".
== References == {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Result}} [[Category:Cricket terminology]] [[Category:Cricket captaincy and tactics]] [[Category:Cricket laws and regulations]]

{{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Bowling techniques sidebar |expanded=all}} '''Spin bowling''' is a [[bowling (cricket)|bowling]] technique in [[cricket]] and the bowler is referred to as a '''spinner'''.
==Purpose== The main aim of spin bowling is to bowl the [[cricket ball]] with rapid rotation so that when it [[bouncing ball|bounces]] on the [[cricket pitch|pitch]] it will deviate from its normal straight path, thus making it difficult for the [[batsman]] to hit the ball cleanly.<ref name="Dummies">Knight, pp.122–123.</ref> The speed the ball travels is not critical, and is significantly slower than that for [[fast bowling]]. A typical spin delivery has a speed in the range 70–90 km/h (45–55 mph). However, in 2010 [[Shahid Afridi]] of Pakistan bowled the fastest spin delivery of 134  km/h in a T20 match against New Zealand<ref>{{cite web|url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3uvunk3XtvE | title= Fastest spin ball bowled |publisher=youtube.com|accessdate=4 June 2015}}</ref>
==Techniques== [[Image:Off break small.gif|frame|right|An off-spin delivery by (right arm over the wicket).]] [[Image:Leg break small.gif|frame|right|A leg-spin delivery by (right arm over the wicket).]]
Spin bowling is divided into four different categories, depending on the particular physical technique used. There is virtually no overlap between the two basic biomechanical techniques of [[wrist spin]] and [[finger spin]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://cricketsecrets.com/2010/08/spin-bowling-tip/| title= Spin Bowling Tips|publisher=CricketSecrets.com|accessdate=4 February 2015}}</ref> <!-- DO NOT ALPHABETISE THIS LIST --> * [[Off break]] – Right-handed with finger spin technique. (e.g. [[Muttiah Muralitharan]], [[saqlain Mushtaq]], [[Nathan Lyon]]) * [[Left-arm orthodox spin]] – Left-handed with finger spin technique. (e.g. [[Daniel Vettori]], [[Rangana Herath]], [[Shakib Al Hasan]]) * [[Leg break]] – Right-handed with wrist spin technique. (e.g. [[Shane Warne]], [[Abdul Qadir (cricketer, born 1955)|Abdul Qadir]], [[Anil Kumble]]) * [[Left-arm unorthodox spin]] – Left-handed with wrist spin technique. (e.g. [[Brad Hogg]], [[Paul Adams (cricketer)|Paul Adams]], [[Chuck Fleetwood-Smith]]) Depending on technique, a spin bowler uses either predominant wrist or finger motion to impart spin to the ball around a horizontal axis that is at an oblique angle to the length of the pitch. This sort of spin means it is also possible for the [[Magnus effect]] to cause the ball to deviate sideways through the air, before it bounces. Such deviation is called ''drift''.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://spinbowlingtips.com/drift/|title= Drift| publisher=SpinBowlingTips.com|accessdate=4 February 2015}}</ref> The combination of drift and spin can make the ball's trajectory complex, with a change of direction at the bounce.
This variety of trajectories achievable by a spin bowler can bewilder inexperienced or poor batsmen.
Spin bowlers are generally given the task of bowling with an old, worn cricket ball. A new cricket ball better suits the techniques of fast bowling than spin bowling, while a worn one grips the pitch better and achieves greater spin.<ref name="Dummies" /> Spin bowlers are also more effective later in a game, as the pitch dries up and begins to crack and crumble. This again provides more purchase for the spinning ball and produces greater deviation. Spin bowlers that open the bowling are rare, but became a more a viable option with the introduction of [[Twenty20 cricket]] when pitch conditions are in their favour, and the ball also generally drifts more in the air.
==Equivalences== Both finger spin and wrist spin bowlers use a range of different angles of spin to confuse the batsman and dismiss him. Many of these variations have direct equivalents in the other discipline, but the names used for the various deliveries may be different.
{| class=wikitable |- !colspan=3|Analogous concepts and terminology<ref>Brian Wilkins "The Bowler's Art"</ref> |- ! Description ! Finger spin ! Wrist spin |- | A delivery in which the ball spins towards the batsman to produce dip and bounce. | topspinner | topspinner |- | A delivery in which the ball spins in the opposite direction to the stock delivery. | doosra (a.k.a. wrong 'un) | googly (a.k.a. wrong 'un or bosey) |- | A delivery in which the ball spins away from the batsmen, scrambed seam. | slider | slider |- | A delivery in which the ball spins away from the batsmen, seam upright to produce swing. | arm ball | also the slider – rarely used |- | A delivery in which the ball is squeezed out of the fingers with backspin. | no real equivalent | flipper |- | A delivery in which the ball spins horizontally on its axis to produce drift but no turn. | undercutter | no real equivalent |}
==Conditions== In recent times, spin bowling has been a forte of the bowlers from the South Asian sub-continent. The primary reason for that is that the pitches in the sub-continent provide more help to the spin bowlers. The faster the pitch degenerates, the earlier the spinners come into the picture. Australian and South African pitches are usually very hard and bouncy, helping the fast bowlers more. They do not break up very much during the duration of the match. In contrast, pitches in the sub-continent are not that hard. They are not usually held together by the grass as much; hence they break up more quickly and help spin bowlers. In general, leg-spin is considered to be one of the toughest types of bowling in which to keep control of the ball, but it is very effective in picking off wickets.<ref>Bob Woolmer "The Art and Science of Cricket"</ref>
==Flight, turn, bounce, drift, dip== [[File:Cricket-Spin-Bounce.jpg|thumb|Bounce]] [[File:Cricket-Spin-Dip.jpg|thumb|Dip]] [[File:Cricket-Spin-Drift.jpg|thumb|upright=0.5|Drift]] [[File:Cricket-Spin-Flight.jpg|thumb|Flight]]
It is customary among cricket commentators to describe and judge the quality of spin bowling in terms of the characteristics ''flight'', ''turn'', ''bounce'', ''drift'', and ''dip''. All these are arts to deceive the batsman and require lots of practice. The basic trajectory of spin bowling is two-lines-at-an-angle, but the above characteristics (described below) modify this 'normal' trajectory into more complex shapes.
'''Turn:''' How much the ball turns after pitching (e.g. 5 degree deviation after meeting the ground). It depends on the number and direction of revolutions of the ball. The movement and rotation of the ball varies, depending on the position of the wrist and the finger. An occasional unexpected straight ball can usefully be included in an attack, but spin variation is the main technique used to deceive the batsman and take wickets. A high rate of turn is above 33 rev/second, or 2000 rpm, which [[Graeme Swann]] consistently spin over 2000 rpm, the most amongst English spinners until [[Liam Dawson]] also topped 35 rev/second, or 2100 rpm. Also, the slower the ball, it tends to deviate more. For an offspinner, you will have to bowl from a wider of off-stump to get the ball to turn into the right-handed batsman and force them to nick off the edge to a fielder or into the top of off stump.
'''Bounce:''' Getting the ball to bounce more than normal, so that the ball meets the batsman at a greater height than expected. Sometimes, if the ball spins horizontally (e.g. a slider), the batsman will not be able to make contact with the ball and it may hit the stumps before the second bounce.
'''Drift:''' Getting the ball to move sideways while in air. Late drift causes the batsman to cover the wrong line and the ball may catch the edge of the bat.
'''Dip:''' Getting the ball to pitch (meet the ground) at a shorter distance than normal. Late dip causes the batsman to misjudge the length of the ball.
'''[[Flight (cricket)|Flight]]:''' throwing the ball up a bit more than normal, so that its time in the air before pitching is longer. A slow ball with extra flight may deceive the batsman into thinking it is slower than it is and therefore mistiming his shot. This is very effective for offspinners. Usually a spin bowler relies on tricks during flight to produce turn, bounce, drift and dip, or combinations of them.
==See also== * [[Cricket terminology]] * [[Seam bowling]] * [[Swing bowling]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== * [[Surya Prakash Chaturvedi]],''Bharat Ki Spin Parampara'',Rajkamal Prakashan,2007 (this book available only in Hindi) * ''Barclays World of Cricket'', 3rd edition (ed. [[E W Swanton]]), Willow Books, 1986. * Julian Knight, ''Cricket for Dummies'', John Wiley and Sons, 2006
==External links== * [http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport/hi/english/static/in_depth/cricket/2001/spin_bowling/default.stm BBC Guide to Spin Bowling] *<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://stats.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283980.html|title=Records {{!}} Combined Test, ODI and T20I records {{!}} Bowling records {{!}} Most wickets in career {{!}} ESPN Cricinfo|work=Cricinfo|access-date=2017-07-19}}</ref> {{Cricket positions}}
[[Category:Bowling (cricket)]] [[Category:Cricket terminology]]

A '''swingman''' is an athlete capable of playing multiple positions in their sport.
==Basketball== In [[basketball]], the term “swingman” (a.k.a. “wing” or “guard-forward”) denotes a player who can play both the [[shooting guard]] (2) and [[small forward]] (3) positions, and in essence ''swing'' between the positions.<ref>S. Trnini and D. Dizdar, ''System of the Performance Evaluation Criteria Weighted per Positions in the Basketball Game'', 2000</ref> Most swingmen range from 6' 5" (1.96 m) to 6' 9" (2.06 m) in height. The term was first applied to [[John Havlicek]]. Examples of current swingmen include [[Paul George]], [[Klay Thompson]], [[DeMar DeRozan]], [[Jimmy Butler (basketball)|Jimmy Butler]], [[Andrew Wiggins]], [[Vince Carter]], [[LeBron James]], and [[Kyle Korver]]. Examples of retired NBA swingmen include [[Kobe Bryant]], [[Clyde Drexler]], [[George Gervin]], and [[Tracy McGrady]].
==Ice hockey== In [[ice hockey]], a swingman is a player that could play both [[defenceman|defenseman]] and [[forward (ice hockey)|forward]], such as [[Brent Burns]] of the [[San Jose Sharks]] and [[Dustin Byfuglien]] of the [[Winnipeg Jets]].
==Baseball== In baseball, a swingman is a [[pitcher]] who can work either as a [[relief pitcher|reliever]] or as a [[starting pitcher|starter]];<ref>[https://www.bostonglobe.com/sports/2014/02/22/red-sox-expect-chris-capuano-flourish-all-roles/zft7lhtiWBKvYOsMDY6VsJ/story.html Boston Globe]</ref> sometimes, if the pitcher is usually a [[long reliever]], he is called a "spot starter".
==Australian football== The term is also used in [[Australian rules football]], typically to describe a player who can play both in attack and in defence, usually as a key position player. Examples include [[Harry Taylor (Australian rules footballer)|Harry Taylor]], [[Ryan Schoenmakers]], [[Ben Reid]] and [[Jarryd Roughead]].
==See also== *[[Tweener (basketball)|Tweener]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.nba.com/canada/bu_swingmen.html NBA.com – Basketball University]
{{Basketball Positions}}
